metadata.title: Interesting AI/ML Articles You Should Read This Week (June 28) | by Richmond Alake | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Interesting AI/ML Articles You Should Read This Week (June 28)
metadata.description: The articles I read this week were fascinating as many writers presented in their opinion what the future might look like for us. Apart from the usual technical articles I come across on Medium, I…

all_paragraphs: Another week, another batch of Medium articles to get through.
The articles I read this week were fascinating as many writers presented in their opinion what the future might look like for us.
Apart from the usual technical articles I come across on Medium, I feel that its important to explore what the future might hold, especially with the impact a fast-paced field like AI can have.
Our lives today could look entirely different tomorrow.

Life, death, art, passion, sex, choice, mind, AI, and the perfect child, these are just half of the topics Luca Rossi touches on in his very well written article on technologies that will govern many aspects of our lives shortly.

To start, Luca provides a disclaimer and warning to readers as the content of the article dances around the thin line of ethics and morality. Luca urges the reader to have an open mind when digesting the contents presented in the article. But after reading, I will argue that you don’t necessarily need an open mind to be able to fathom the reality of the technologies Luca presents.

Luca correlates the similarities between far fetched presumptions of the future to current-day technologies that are available to us in a manner that made me think that yes all these future technologies are only a couple of generations away.
This article is an excellent read if you would like to find out why only poor people will die in the future, or why a future society could be populated with ‘perfect’ humans.

Luca discusses the fears associated with each of the mentioned future technology. Each section also includes a segment that rationalizes the fear humans may have on the incoming and unpreventable future.

The article is riddled with resources that provide evidence of organization alluding to the path of creating the mentioned future tech. So, for the sceptical readers that feel we might be hundreds of years away from some of the mentioned future technology, Luca’s article might change your mind.

Binh Phan provides information on how Machine learning practitioners can extend the reach of their machine learning models online, at relatively no cost at all. This is made possible through the utilization of computing resources from one of the biggest cloud service providers on the planet.

The article contains clear and concise step by step instructions that makes the end goal very achievable; this is in comparison to many outdated articles out there, which is no fault of the authors, as it is merely a result of the fast-paced advancement of technology.
Binh introduces industry-standard tools such as Docker and GCP.
The end result of the instructions within this article is an external link to access the exposed functionality of a trained machine learning model.

Let’s say you have 10,000 hours to dedicate to becoming the best Data Scientist you can be, then Richard Michael’s article will essentially be the blueprint that structures out how you spend each hour.

Richard has put together a structured approach to how an absolute beginner can become a proficient data scientist by providing resources that cover the foundations of statistics and maths, all through to to the selection of operating systems and programming languages.

Each identified subject area has been allocated some portion of time out of the 10,000 hours needed to become an expert data scientist; so you get a rough estimation of how long each subject area would take to complete.
The second half of Richard’s article dissects the job roles that you’ll find within the machine learning domain.

Many will find that most of the roles within machine learning tend to overlap in terms of their designated duties and responsibilities. But nevertheless, it’s always good to get an understanding of what the end goal of your studies could look like, as this can make your learning path much more transparent.

Adam Tabriz, MD article combines the world of Artificial intelligence and Healthcare, through the portrayal of how AI will impact the day to day roles and services delivered by various healthcare practices.
The non-technical approach of the article makes this a great read for all readers.

Adam starts with a deep dive of the term deep learning and the connotations that come with it. The early contents of the article can be seen as a non-technical explanation of common terms and phrases related to Artificial intelligence.

Adam further explains, in yet again non-technical manner, how AI is applied within industries. Although AI is utilized in a variety of industry for different tasks, Adam’s article explains that the process of each AI system is nonetheless the same across industries.
I won’t put any spoilers in my coverage of Adam’s article, but Adam provides a striking statement that summarizes the overarching goal of the machine learning field.

As we approach the main body of the article, Adam starts writing in a more fast-paced manner. The content of the article within this section begins to focus more on AI within the healthcare industries.
Adam introduces several interesting ideas and technologies, take, for example, the integration of AI with the human mind and the utilization of AI for diagnostic purposes within Healthcare.

The main content of Adam’s article is littered with the immense potential of AI within the healthcare industry. This article will be an excellent read for individuals within the healthcare industry that are curious as to how their work and practice will begin to change in the coming years.
The later part of Adam’s article takes an opposite view from the earlier section, as Adam introduces the negative impact AI can have on society, individuals and day to day lives.

Subjects such as privacy, job retention, weapons, algorithmic bias, and more are explored. It’s only fair that Adam has included the negative, darker aspect of the introduction of AI applications and solutions.
Adam concludes his article by focusing on healthcare professional and their approach to embracing AI and AI-based solutions.

The general message I took from the concluding part of the article is the needs for Healthcare professional to understand the incoming introduction of AI tools to Healthcare, and for them to know how they can unify with AI to deliver the best service to patients and clients.
